The Stone allows academic philosophers to reveal how little they have to say that is logical or well-reasoned -- Rivka Weinberg is the latest example.

Regarding human lifespans in the United States: I know many people who are 80-95 and I don't hear any of them thinking life has been too short -- and some believe they have lived too long.

Since you did a superb column on the jobs question, I did not comment but since this is in my area of experience, I remind your readers that there are plenty of pipeline jobs begging to be funded. For example, old water lines, bridges, tunnels & areas that cannot access cheap natural gas because there is no access to a natural gas pipeline. Many areas must use truck delivered oil for home heating. We need to invest in US projects that broadly benefit the economy of the United States. Now is a perfect time to invest & there are proposals for an Infrastructure Bank and there is an opportunity on the reauthorization of the Surface Transportation Act in action by Spring.

It is shortsighted to miss this opportunity, there are plenty of opportunities to create jobs on projects that will begat more jobs. Everyone knows this. Clearly, we must invest in Public Goods that make economic activity more efficient -- like the Interstate Maglev Network, which can be paid for by the users, The US needs to test and certify the new 2nd generation Maglev developed by Drs. James Powell and Gordon Danby and let their Maglev compete with all of the other transport systems.

I have just finished an excellent book by Nobel Laureate, Edmund Phelps, titled "Mass Flourishing". He makes a good case for "How Grassroots Innovation Created Jobs, Challenge, and Change". Think Erie Canal, Transcontinental Railroad, Interstate Highway System, Freight Containers, Apollo program, nuclear power.

Financing campaigns has severely handicapped democracy by distorting government's priorities away from voter interests. We would be much better off if political campaigns were financed by taxpayers. The simplest thing to do is to issue non-transferable political "script" to every registered voter & let them donate to their favorite candidates or political parties. Spending in kind or in cash would be prohibited unless it was in the form of this political script. Fundamentally, it would return the US to "one person one vote". The industry: political consultants, campaign staffs, campaign vendors (hotels, airlines, buses, food, etc) and media could redeem their certificates at any Federal Reserve Bank. I think about $50,000 in plastic annually to every registered voter should be a healthy start. This one change would broaden the voter base & probably increase voter participation.

A beautiful sentiment, and one that is harder and harder to hold on to. On the same side of your sentiments is the necessary respect we all must offer others, regardless of their religious beliefs, skin color, or political leanings. We all have to show that respect. What you call humorous was clearly horrifying to some groups, and by continuing to publish these cartoons, the editors of the tabloid were not showing the respect necessary for our multicultural societies to function well. Being a satirical publication should not release anyone from being respectful to neighbors, or anyone. This should be obvious, but there is no excuse for these horrific murders. My point is that respect of others beliefs must be primary for this multicultural experiment we are all involved in.

We are human beings. We laugh. We cry. We rejoice. We suffer. We have hopes, dreams, fears, wishes, relatives, friends, enemies, fingers and toes. We are Jewish, Muslim, Buddhist, Hindu, Rastafarian, Shinto, Atheist, Christian, etc. We all bleed red. We all feel pain. We are more alike than different.

I am afraid of becoming indifferent to these tragedies. They have become so common. I'm worried that at some point all I will do is shrug my shoulders because the news of bloodied bodies and ruined lives will have no ability to shock me to my core. It still does. I worry that we will forget that the pain in our hearts is the pain that another heart can feel when tragedy strikes. And I wonder at the hearts that plan these horrors. What made them capable of committing such crimes? Why is it a crime to be satirical? What God demands vengeance for humor? Is humor that someone disagrees with all it takes to start a massacre or a war? I suspect that there are no answers unless we look at each other and see each other as human beings not as sects or religions or colors.

All I can say besides I'm sorry is this: I am human and the spear in your heart is the pain in mine.

Not long ago I heard an obese young woman at an Overeaters Anonymous meeting share about how she trained and ran distance races in an attempt to show the world that it didn't make any difference if she was obese. But after joining OA and feeling comfortable enough to speak the truth, she admitted it was just a way to allow herself to continue to compulsively eat without feeling always guilty. That admitting that she was powerless over food was the first step she needed to take to change her relationship with food.

Not long ago I watched a pudgy fifty-ish woman run a half marathon in 1 hour 45 minutes. I would not call her obese, but her BMI was definitely above recommended levels. If she keeps up that pace, I doubt she will ever be unhealthy. Thin athletic people sometimes have heart disease. Sadly because they don't look like they'd be sick, they are under-diagnosed and die.

There's a place for medicine by the numbers, but each person must be looked at as an individual.

The commenter Michael Cohen is yet another austerity fan who uses made up historical facts to support his position. Apparently "we are all aware that despite all attempts by FDR to grow the economy, it was stalled until WWII.." If Mr Cohen and his ilk weren't so sure of this "fact," he and they would have spent ten minutes or so to actually look up GDP and unemployment figures for the FDR years: except for a brief downturn 1937 when FDR gave into the austerity freaks of his era, both the GDP and unemployment rates improve nearly linearly from the start of FDR's programs.

"The trouble ain't what people don't know, it's what they know that ain't so." attr. Josh Billings.

Just compare post WWI with post WWII.

After WWI we had 10 years of surpluses, This sucked money out of the private sector like leeching blood from a patient. By October of 1929 we had reduced the debt by 38%; it was only 16% of GDP. And then the economy fell off a cliff.

After WWII we had deficits for most of the years from 1946 - 1947. We increased the debt by 75%. And we started out with highest debt in the history of the US of A as a percent of GDP. Considerably higher than today. Not only did we not have a depression, but we had prosperity. GDP growth averaged 3.8% and real median household income surged 74%.

The core problem that of inadequate demand requires much scrutiny.   We are all aware that despite all attempts byFDRto grow the economy, it was stalled until WWII and there is no World War in the offing to boost our economy.  Also heavy deficit spending in Japan did not get the Japanese economy out of its 15 year long bout with deflation.   A discussion of why one expects success for a policy which in Japan failed merits discussion.  It is not obvious that large deficit spending on infrastructure, a good idea in any event will cure our economic ills.  Evidence on this point would be worthwhile

Exactly right. Environmental benefits come from reducing demand, not from reducing supply. Gasoline demand is currently going down while vehicle miles driven are going up, so efficiency improvements are making a difference.

I think sometimes we're so busy concluding, thinking, philosophizing, estimating, judging, questioning, overcoming, assuming all the absurdity of existence, that we forget to exist. We can never understand the immensity of life because we never allow ourselves to. I think it's in that existing, all determining dissolves. But we can never arrive to the state of dissolution because we've accepted the limited possibility that life is this tremendous obstacle, this clown suit that is constantly standing in the way.

Maybe the only thing standing in the way is the ego, the thing that thinks it knows. And maybe if we distanced ourself from this state of ego, only then transcendence could occur. Transcendence not as magical, not as something that requires faith, just pure daringness, pure intelligence. So that we could arrive at an understanding where absurdity was never an obstacle, but all along something to propel us to a state where the absurdity of it all was no longer bothersome. In these situations I like to go back to Dawkins and his characterization of us living things as survival machines 'designed' by evolution to carry our genes into the next generation.

And now there are the memes which use our consciousness to replicate, the memes which in aggregate are our culture. I think our consciousness and culture are so newly evolved, they are at the level of a baby: the dazzlement at shiny things, the solipsism, and especially the absurdities that we can't seem to shake (though narrowing them down to the time domain seems like a good start!).

But a meme can evolve inside a single mind over the course of weeks and years rather than the billions of years needed by the blind watch-maker. So one of the self-assigned meanings for my life is to to try re-wire the meme-set of my culture. Maybe tilt it to be a little more rational, a little more enjoyable. I won't be around to enjoy the fruits of hard won rationality, but maybe someone wearing some of my memes will. And I can't even imagine the levels of absurdity he'll be dealing with.
